article.title: Spin states of asteroids in the Eos collisional family

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the V-shape envelope in the top panel of Figure 1 represent?
choices: The initial extent of the Eos family and the varying strengths of the Yarkovsky drift on its members.
The distribution of albedo values for Eos family members.
The location of interlopers within the Eos family.
The orbital resonances affecting the Eos family.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the top right panel of Figure 2 demonstrate about the Eos family?
choices: The ecliptic pole-latitude distribution is uniform, suggesting random spin axis orientations.
The ecliptic pole-latitude distribution is bi-modal, with an excess of retrograde rotators at larger semi-major axes.
The distribution of spin axis longitudes is non-uniform, indicating a preferred alignment.
Larger asteroids in the Eos family are more likely to have retrograde rotations.

multiple_choice_question.text: What bias is evident in the rotation period distributions shown in the bottom right panel of Figure 3?
choices: An overrepresentation of slow rotators due to the ease of measuring long rotation periods.
An overrepresentation of fast rotators due to the preference for observing objects with large lightcurve amplitudes.
An underrepresentation of medium rotators due to their lower occurrence in the main asteroid belt.
A lack of data for very small asteroids due to limitations in observational capabilities.

multiple_choice_question.text: What conclusion about asteroid (423) Diotima can be drawn from Figure A.4?
choices: Diotima is a confirmed member of the Eos family, as its shape and size are consistent with other family members.
Diotima\'s shape model, derived from disk-resolved images, confirms its unusually high density for a C-type asteroid.
The comparison between model projections and AO images validates the shape model and supports the classification of Diotima as a K-type asteroid.
The figure supports the classification of Diotima as a C-type asteroid, further indicating it is an interloper in the Eos family.
